--- title: "Chapter 4 Part 1" subtitle: "Logistic Regression" format: revealjs: output-file: "04-logistic.qmd" slide-number: true html: output-file: "04-logistic_o.qmd" --- ## Recap {.small} * We had a _linear regression_ refresher * Linear regression is a great tool when we have a continuous outcome * We are going to learn some fancy ways to do even better in the future *Setup:* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(broom) library(tidymodels) library(gridExtra) library(ISLR) ``` ::: # Classification ## Classification {.smaller} :::question What are some examples of classification problems? ::: * Qualitative response variable in an _unordered set_, $\mathcal{C}$ * `eye color` $\in$ `{blue, brown, green}` * `email` $\in$ `{spam, not spam}` * Response, $Y$ takes on values in $\mathcal{C}$ * Predictors are a vector, $X$ * The task: build a function $C(X)$ that takes $X$ and predicts $Y$, $C(X)\in\mathcal{C}$ * Many times we are actually more interested in the _probabilities_ that $X$ belongs to each category in $\mathcal{C}$ ## Example: Credit card default ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} set.seed(1) Default |> sample_frac(size = 0.25) |> ggplot(aes(balance, income, color = default)) + geom_point(pch = 4) + scale_color_manual(values = c("cornflower blue", "red")) + theme_classic() + theme(legend.position = "top") -> p1 p2 <- ggplot(Default, aes(x = default, y = balance, fill = default)) + geom_boxplot() + scale_fill_manual(values = c("cornflower blue", "red")) + theme_classic() + theme(legend.position = "none") p3 <- ggplot(Default, aes(x = default, y = income, fill = default)) + geom_boxplot() + scale_fill_manual(values = c("cornflower blue", "red")) + theme_classic() + theme(legend.position = "none") grid.arrange(p1, p2, p3, ncol = 3, widths = c(2, 1, 1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-logistic_files/figure-revealjs/plot1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Can we use linear regression? {.small} We can code `Default` as $$Y = \begin{cases} 0 & \textrm{if }\texttt{No}\\ 1&\textrm{if }\texttt{Yes}\end{cases}$$ Can we fit a linear regression of $Y$ on $X$ and classify as `Yes` if $\hat{Y}> 0.5$? * In this case of a **binary** outcome, linear regression is okay (it is equivalent to **linear discriminant analysis**, you can read more about that in your book!) * $E[Y|X=x] = P(Y=1|X=x)$, so it seems like this is a pretty good idea! * **The problem**: Linear regression can produce probabilities less than 0 or greater than 1 ðŸ˜± ## Can we use linear regression? {.small} We can code `Default` as $$Y = \begin{cases} 0 & \textrm{if }\texttt{No}\\ 1&\textrm{if }\texttt{Yes}\end{cases}$$ Can we fit a linear regression of $Y$ on $X$ and classify as `Yes` if $\hat{Y}> 0.5$? ::: question What may do a better job? ::: * **Logistic regression!** ## Linear versus logistic regression {.small} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} Default <- Default |> mutate( p = glm(default ~ balance, data = Default, family = "binomial") |> predict(type = "response"), p2 = lm(I(default == "Yes") ~ balance, data = Default) |> predict(), def = ifelse(default == "Yes", 1, 0) ) Default |> sample_frac(0.25) |> ggplot(aes(balance, p2)) + geom_hline(yintercept = c(0, 1), lty = 2, size = 0.2) + geom_line(color = "cornflower blue") + geom_point(aes(balance, def), shape = "|", color = "orange") + theme_classic() + labs(y = "probability of default") -> p1 Default |> sample_frac(0.25) |> ggplot(aes(balance, p)) + geom_hline(yintercept = c(0, 1), lty = 2, size = 0.2) + geom_line(color = "cornflower blue") + geom_point(aes(balance, def), shape = "|", color = "orange") + theme_classic() + labs(y = "probability of default") -> p2 grid.arrange(p1, p2, ncol = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-logistic_files/figure-revealjs/plot2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::question Which does a better job at predicting the probability of default? ::: * The orange marks represent the response $Y\in\{0,1\}$ ## Linear Regression {.small} What if we have $>2$ possible outcomes? For example, someone comes to the emergency room and we need to classify them according to their symptoms $$ \begin{align} Y = \begin{cases} 1& \textrm{if }\texttt{stroke}\\2&\textrm{if }\texttt{drug overdose}\\3&\textrm{if }\texttt{epileptic seizure}\end{cases} \end{align} $$ :::question What could go wrong here? ::: * The coding implies an _ordering_ * The coding implies _equal spacing_ (that is the difference between `stroke` and `drug overdose` is the same as `drug overdose` and `epileptic seizure`) ## Linear Regression {.small} What if we have $>2$ possible outcomes? For example, someone comes to the emergency room and we need to classify them according to their symptoms $$ \begin{align} Y = \begin{cases} 1& \textrm{if }\texttt{stroke}\\2&\textrm{if }\texttt{drug overdose}\\3&\textrm{if }\texttt{epileptic seizure}\end{cases} \end{align} $$ * Linear regression is **not** appropriate here * **Mutliclass logistic regression** or **discriminant analysis** are more appropriate ## Logistic Regression {.small} $$ p(X) = \frac{e^{\beta_0+\beta_1X}}{1+e^{\beta_0+\beta_1X}} $$ * Note: $p(X)$ is shorthand for $P(Y=1|X)$ * No matter what values $\beta_0$, $\beta_1$, or $X$ take $p(X)$ will always be between 0 and 1 ## Logistic Regression {.small} $$ p(X) = \frac{e^{\beta_0+\beta_1X}}{1+e^{\beta_0+\beta_1X}} $$ We can rearrange this into the following form: $$ \log\left(\frac{p(X)}{1-p(X)}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X $$ :::question What is this transformation called? ::: * This is a **log odds** or **logit** transformation of $p(X)$ ## Linear versus logistic regression ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-logistic_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: Logistic regression ensures that our estimates for $p(X)$ are between 0 and 1 ðŸŽ‰ ## Maximum Likelihood :::question Refresher: How did we estimate $\hat\beta$ in linear regression? ::: ## Maximum Likelihood {.small} :::question Refresher: How did we estimate $\hat\beta$ in linear regression? ::: In logistic regression, we use **maximum likelihood** to estimate the parameters $$\mathcal{l}(\beta_0,\beta_1)=\prod_{i:y_i=1}p(x_i)\prod_{i:y_i=0}(1-p(x_i))$$ * This **likelihood** give the probability of the observed ones and zeros in the data * We pick $\beta_0$ and $\beta_1$ to maximize the likelihood * _We'll let `R` do the heavy lifting here_ ## Let's see it in R {.small} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(default ~ balance, data = Default) |> tidy() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) -10.7 0.361 -29.5 3.62e-191 2 balance 0.00550 0.000220 25.0 1.98e-137 ``` ::: ::: * Use the `logistic_reg()` function in R with the `glm` engine ## Making predictions :::question What is our estimated probability of default for someone with a balance of $1000? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
term estimate std.error statistic p.value
(Intercept) -10.6513306 0.3611574 -29.49221 0
balance 0.0054989 0.0002204 24.95309 0
````` ::: ::: . . . $$ \hat{p}(X) = \frac{e^{\hat{\beta}_0+\hat{\beta}_1X}}{1+e^{\hat{\beta}_0+\hat{\beta}_1X}}=\frac{e^{-10.65+0.0055\times 1000}}{1+e^{-10.65+0.0055\times 1000}}=0.006 $$ ## Making predictions :::question What is our estimated probability of default for someone with a balance of $2000? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
term estimate std.error statistic p.value
(Intercept) -10.6513306 0.3611574 -29.49221 0
balance 0.0054989 0.0002204 24.95309 0
````` ::: ::: . . . $$ \hat{p}(X) = \frac{e^{\hat{\beta}_0+\hat{\beta}_1X}}{1+e^{\hat{\beta}_0+\hat{\beta}_1X}}=\frac{e^{-10.65+0.0055\times 2000}}{1+e^{-10.65+0.0055\times 2000}}=0.586 $$ ## Logistic regression example {.small} Let's refit the model to predict the probability of default given the customer is a `student` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
term estimate std.error statistic p.value
(Intercept) -3.5041278 0.0707130 -49.554219 0.0000000
studentYes 0.4048871 0.1150188 3.520181 0.0004313
````` ::: ::: $$P(\texttt{default = Yes}|\texttt{student = Yes}) = \frac{e^{-3.5041+0.4049\times1}}{1+e^{-3.5041+0.4049\times1}}=0.0431$$ . . . :::question How will this change if student = No? ::: . . . $$P(\texttt{default = Yes}|\texttt{student = No}) = \frac{e^{-3.5041+0.4049\times0}}{1+e^{-3.5041+0.4049\times0}}=0.0292$$ ## Potential Confounding {.small} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-logistic_files/figure-revealjs/plot3-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::question What is going on here? ::: ## Confounding {.small} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](04-logistic_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: * Students tend to have higher balances than non-students * Their **marginal** default rate is higher * For each level of balance, students default less * Their **conditional** default rate is lower ## A bit about "odds" {.small} * The "odds" tell you how likely an event is * ðŸŒ‚ Let's say there is a 60% chance of rain today * What is the probability that it will rain? * $p = 0.6$ * What is the probability that it **won't** rain? * $1-p = 0.4$ * What are the **odds** that it will rain? * 3 to 2, 3:2, $\frac{0.6}{0.4} = 1.5$ ## Transforming logs {.small} * How do you "undo" a $\log$ base $e$? * Use $e$! For example: * $e^{\log(10)} = 10$ * $e^{\log(1283)} = 1283$ * $e^{\log(x)} = x$ ## Transforming logs {.small} ::: question How would you get the odds from the log(odds)? ::: ::: nonincremental * How do you "undo" a $\log$ base $e$? * Use $e$! For example: * $e^{\log(10)} = 10$ * $e^{\log(1283)} = 1283$ * $e^{\log(x)} = x$ ::: * $e^{\log(odds)}$ = odds ## Transforming odds {.small} * odds = $\frac{\pi}{1-\pi}$ * Solving for $\pi$ * $\pi = \frac{\textrm{odds}}{1+\textrm{odds}}$ * Plugging in $e^{\log(odds)}$ = odds * $\pi = \frac{e^{\log(odds)}}{1+e^{\log(odds)}}$ * Plugging in $\log(odds) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x$ * $\pi = \frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1x}}{1+e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1x}}$ ## The logistic model * âœŒï¸ forms Form | Model -----|------ Logit form | $\log\left(\frac{\pi}{1-\pi}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x$ Probability form | $\Large\pi = \frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1x}}{1+e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1x}}$ ## The logistic model probability | odds | log(odds) --|--|-- $\pi$ | $\frac{\pi}{1-\pi}$ | $\log\left(\frac{\pi}{1-\pi}\right)=l$ â¬…ï¸ log(odds) | odds | probability --|--|-- $l$ | $e^l$ | $\frac{e^l}{1+e^l} = \pi$ ## The logistic model {.small} * âœŒï¸ forms * **log(odds)**: $l = \beta_0 + \beta_1x$ * **P(Outcome = Yes)**: $\Large\pi =\frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1x}}{1+e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1x}}$ ## Odds ratios {.small} A study investigated whether a handheld device that sends a magnetic pulse into a personâ€™s head might be an effective treatment for migraine headaches. * Researchers recruited 200 subjects who suffered from migraines * randomly assigned them to receive either the TMS (transcranial magnetic stimulation) treatment or a placebo treatment * Subjects were instructed to apply the device at the onset of migraine symptoms and then assess how they felt two hours later. (either **Pain-free** or **Not pain-free**) ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What is the explanatory variable? ::: A study investigated whether a handheld device that sends a magnetic pulse into a personâ€™s head might be an effective treatment for migraine headaches. ::: nonincremental * Researchers recruited 200 subjects who suffered from migraines * randomly assigned them to receive either the TMS (transcranial magnetic stimulation) treatment or a placebo treatment * Subjects were instructed to apply the device at the onset of migraine symptoms and then assess how they felt two hours later (either **Pain-free** or **Not pain-free**) ::: ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What type of variable is this? ::: A study investigated whether a handheld device that sends a magnetic pulse into a personâ€™s head might be an effective treatment for migraine headaches. ::: nonincremental * Researchers recruited 200 subjects who suffered from migraines * randomly assigned them to receive either the TMS (transcranial magnetic stimulation) treatment or a placebo treatment * Subjects were instructed to apply the device at the onset of migraine symptoms and then assess how they felt two hours later (either **Pain-free** or **Not pain-free**) ::: ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What is the outcome variable? ::: A study investigated whether a handheld device that sends a magnetic pulse into a personâ€™s head might be an effective treatment for migraine headaches. ::: nonincremental * Researchers recruited 200 subjects who suffered from migraines * randomly assigned them to receive either the TMS (transcranial magnetic stimulation) treatment or a placebo treatment * Subjects were instructed to apply the device at the onset of migraine symptoms and then assess how they felt two hours later (either **Pain-free** or **Not pain-free**) ::: ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What type of variable is this? ::: A study investigated whether a handheld device that sends a magnetic pulse into a personâ€™s head might be an effective treatment for migraine headaches. ::: nonincremental * Researchers recruited 200 subjects who suffered from migraines * randomly assigned them to receive either the TMS (transcranial magnetic stimulation) treatment or a placebo treatment * Subjects were instructed to apply the device at the onset of migraine symptoms and then assess how they felt two hours later (either **Pain-free** or **Not pain-free**) ::: ## Odds ratios {.smaller} Treatment |TMS | Placebo| Total| |---|---|----|---| |Pain-free two hours later |39| 22 |61| |Not pain-free two hours later |61 |78| 139| |Total| 100| 100 |200| * We can compare the results using **odds** * What are the odds of being pain-free for the placebo group? * $(22/100)/(78/100) = 22/78 = 0.282$ * What are the odds of being pain-free for the treatment group? * $39/61 = 0.639$ * Comparing the **odds** what can we conclude? * TMS increases the likelihood of success ## Odds ratios {.small} Treatment |TMS | Placebo| Total ---|---|----|--- Pain-free two hours later |39| 22 |61 Not pain-free two hours later |61 |78| 139 Total| 100| 100 |200 * We can summarize this relationship with an **odds ratio**: the ratio of the two odds * $\Large OR = \frac{39/61}{22/78} = \frac{0.639}{0.282} = 2.27$ * _"the odds of being pain free were 2.27 times higher with TMS than with the placebo"_ ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What if we wanted to calculate this in terms of Not pain-free (with pain-free) as the referent? ::: Treatment |TMS | Placebo| Total ---|---|----|--- Pain-free two hours later |39| 22 |61 Not pain-free two hours later |61 |78| 139 Total| 100| 100 |200 * $\Large OR = \frac{61/39}{78/22} = \frac{1.564}{3.545} = 0.441$ * _the odds for still being in pain for the TMS group are 0.441 times the odds of being in pain for the placebo group_ ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What changed here? ::: Treatment |TMS | Placebo| Total ---|---|----|--- Pain-free two hours later |39| 22 |61 Not pain-free two hours later |61 |78| 139 Total| 100| 100 |200 * $\Large OR = \frac{78/22}{61/39} = \frac{3.545}{1.564} = 2.27$ * _the odds for still being in pain for the placebo group are 2.27 times the odds of being in pain for the TMS group_ ## Odds ratios {.small} In general, it's more natural to interpret odds ratios > 1, you can flip the referent to do so Treatment |TMS | Placebo| Total ---|---|----|--- Pain-free two hours later |39| 22 |61 Not pain-free two hours later |61 |78| 139 Total| 100| 100 |200 $\Large OR = \frac{78/22}{61/39} = \frac{3.545}{1.564} = 2.27$ _the odds for still being in pain for the placebo group are 2.27 times the odds of being in pain for the TMS group_ ## Odds ratios {.small} Let's look at some Titanic data. We are interested in whether the passenger reported being female is related to whether they survived. ::: {.cell} ::: ||Female | Male | Total ---------|-------|-----|----- Survived| 308 | 142 | 450 Died | 154 | 709| 863 Total | 462 | 851 | 1313 ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What are the odds of surviving for females versus males? ::: ||Female | Male | Total ---------|-------|-----|----- Survived| 308 | 142 | 450 Died | 154 | 709| 863 Total | 462 | 851 | 1313 $$\Large OR = \frac{308/154}{142/709} = \frac{2}{0.2} = 9.99$$ ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question How do you interpret this? ::: ||Female | Male | Total ---------|-------|-----|----- Survived| 308 | 142 | 450 Died | 154 | 709| 863 Total | 462 | 851 | 1313 $$\Large OR = \frac{308/154}{142/709} = \frac{2}{0.2} = 9.99$$ _the odds of surviving for the female passengers was 9.99 times the odds of surviving for the male passengers_ ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question What if we wanted to fit a model? What would the equation be? ::: ||Female | Male | Total ---------|-------|-----|----- Survived| 308 | 142 | 450 Died | 154 | 709| 863 Total | 462 | 851 | 1313 . . . $$\Large \log(\textrm{odds of survival}) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \textrm{Female}$$ ## Odds ratios {.small} $$\Large \log(\textrm{odds of survival}) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \textrm{Female}$$ ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Survived ~ Sex, data = Titanic) |> tidy() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) -1.61 0.0919 -17.5 1.70e-68 2 Sexfemale 2.30 0.135 17.1 2.91e-65 ``` ::: ::: ## Odds Ratios {.small} ::: question How do you interpret this result? ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Survived ~ Sex, data = Titanic) |> tidy() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) -1.61 0.0919 -17.5 1.70e-68 2 Sexfemale 2.30 0.135 17.1 2.91e-65 ``` ::: ::: ## Odds Ratios {.small} ::: question How do you interpret this result? ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="4"} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Survived ~ Sex, data = Titanic) |> tidy(exponentiate = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) 0.200 0.0919 -17.5 1.70e-68 2 Sexfemale 9.99 0.135 17.1 2.91e-65 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="4"} exp(2.301176) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 9.99 ``` ::: ::: ## Odds Ratios {.small} ::: question How do you interpret this result? ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Survived ~ Sex, data = Titanic) |> tidy(exponentiate = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) 0.200 0.0919 -17.5 1.70e-68 2 Sexfemale 9.99 0.135 17.1 2.91e-65 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} exp(2.301176) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 9.99 ``` ::: ::: _the odds of surviving for the female passengers was 9.99 times the odds of surviving for the male passengers_ ## Odds ratios {.small} What if the explanatory variable is continuous? ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Acceptance ~ GPA, data = MedGPA) |> tidy() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) -19.2 5.63 -3.41 0.000644 2 GPA 5.45 1.58 3.45 0.000553 ``` ::: ::: _A one unit increase in GPA yields a 5.45 increase in the log odds of acceptance_ ## Odds ratios {.small} What if the explanatory variable is continuous? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Acceptance ~ GPA, data = MedGPA) |> tidy(exponentiate = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) 4.56e-9 5.63 -3.41 0.000644 2 GPA 2.34e+2 1.58 3.45 0.000553 ``` ::: ::: _A one unit increase in GPA yields a 234-fold increase in the odds of acceptance_ * ðŸ˜± that seems huge! **Remember:** the interpretation of these coefficients depends on your units (the same as in ordinary linear regression). ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question How could we get the odds associated with increasing GPA by 0.1? ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Acceptance ~ GPA, data = MedGPA) |> tidy() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) -19.2 5.63 -3.41 0.000644 2 GPA 5.45 1.58 3.45 0.000553 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exp(5.454) ## a one unit increase in GPA ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 234 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} exp(5.454 * 0.1) ## a 0.1 increase in GPA ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1.73 ``` ::: ::: _A one-tenth unit increase in GPA yields a 1.73-fold increase in the odds of acceptance_ ## Odds ratios {.small} ::: question How could we get the odds associated with increasing GPA by 0.1? ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} MedGPA <- MedGPA |> mutate(GPA_10 = GPA * 10) logistic_reg() |> set_engine("glm") |> fit(Acceptance ~ GPA_10, data = MedGPA) |> tidy(exponentiate = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 5 term estimate std.error statistic p.value 1 (Intercept) 0.00000000456 5.63 -3.41 0.000644 2 GPA_10 1.73 0.158 3.45 0.000553 ``` ::: ::: _A one-tenth unit increase in GPA yields a 1.73-fold increase in the odds of acceptance_ ## ``{=html} `Application Exercise` Using the `Default` data from the `ISLR` package. Fit two logistic regression models that predict whether a customer `defaults` - One model with `student` as a predictor. Interpret the coefficient of `studentYes`. - Another model with `balance` as a predictor. Interpret the coefficient of `balance`. Here is some code to get you started: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ISLR) data("Default") ``` :::

      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
